byline.contributor: Chris Buckley reported from Shenzhen, and Austin Ramzy from Hong Kong. Research was contributed by Adam Wu from Shenzhen, and Vanessa Piao, Kiki Zhao and Owen Guo from Beijing.
byline.original: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and AUSTIN RAMZY

abstract: Landslide of dirt and construction debris buries or topples 33 buildings in Shenzhen, China, leaving 81 people missing; it is latest man-made disaster pointing up risks of quick urban growth, in which many buildings are constructed quickly; news media says officials have allowed risks to persist.
lead_paragraph: China’s rapid construction of new buildings, and the short life of many of those structures, have long created problems with unregulated dumping of construction waste.

headline.main: Shenzhen, Embodying China’s Growth, Falls Risk to It
headline.print_headline: City Embodying China’s Growth Falls Risk to It

snippet: China’s rapid construction of new buildings, and the short life of many of those structures, have long created problems with unregulated dumping of construction waste.
